patterns.name: Dame-Dame
patterns.description: A checkerboard pattern representing duality and balance
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Dame-Dame (checker) pattern represents duality in Akan philosophy. It symbolizes the balance between opposites - like light and dark, joy and sorrow, the seen and unseen.

patterns.name: Babadua
patterns.description: Horizontal stripes pattern representing cooperation and unity
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Babadua pattern represents cooperation and unity in community. The horizontal lines symbolize people working together in harmony.

patterns.name: Nkyinkyim
patterns.description: Zigzag pattern representing life's journey and adaptability
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Nkyinkyim (zigzag) pattern symbolizes life's journey and adaptability. It represents the ability to change direction when faced with obstacles, and the twists and turns of life's path.

patterns.name: Kubi
patterns.description: Vertical stripes pattern representing strength and power
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Kubi pattern represents strength and power. The vertical lines symbolize upright character and moral integrity.

patterns.name: Eban
patterns.description: Square pattern representing security and safety
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Eban pattern represents security, safety, and home. The enclosed square symbolizes protection and shelter.

patterns.name: Obaakofo
patterns.description: Diamond pattern representing leadership and excellence
patterns.culturalSignificance: The Obaakofo pattern represents leadership and excellence. The diamond shape symbolizes the precious qualities of a good leader.
